datafield.subfield: BTau primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010 (/BTau/Run-2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD)
BTau primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in
Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of more than one isolated tau in the event, or because of presence of low-energy muons from b-quark decay.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
CMS data quality monitoring: Systems and experiences
The CMS Data Quality Monitoring software experience and future improvements
The CMS data quality monitoring software: experience and future prospects

ZeroBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010 (/ZeroBias/Run2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD)
ZeroBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in

Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of low-energy particles (soft QCD events). It is a beam bunch crossing-time trigger used to obtain a “zero bias” data sample, e.g. a trigger on random (filled) bunches.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
CMS data quality monitoring: Systems and experiences
The CMS Data Quality Monitoring software experience and future improvements
The CMS data quality monitoring software: experience and future prospects

Commissioning primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in
Events stored in this primary dataset were selected for detector commissioning purposes.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

EGMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010 (/EGMonitor/Run2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD)</subfield)
EGMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in

Dedicated primary dataset for detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of at least one high-energy electron in the event, but the acceptance criteria for these electrons are different than those of the Electron primary dataset.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

MultiJet primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010 (/MultiJet/Run2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD)</subfield)
MultiJet primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in
Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence two or more high-energy jets, and requiring a high HT, defined as the sum of the energy of all jets in the event.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. MuMonitor primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in

Dedicated primary dataset for detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of at least one muon in the event. The acceptance criteria for these muons are different than those of the Mu primary dataset.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

MinimumBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010 (/MinimumBias/Run2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD)</subfield)
MinimumBias primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in

Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of low-energy particles (soft QCD events). This trigger is favourable over the ZeroBias when the luminosity, and thus the rate of collisions to tape, is too low for ZeroBias to be effective.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:

Dedicated primary dataset detector monitoring. Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of a low-energy central jet in the event, tau jets or high missing transverse energy.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. METFwd primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in
Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of high missing transverse energy per event or because of presence of at least two forward-backward jets.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. Mu primary dataset in AOD format from RunB of 2010
This dataset contains all runs from 2010 RunB. The list of validated runs, which must be applied to all analyses, can be found in

Events stored in this primary dataset were selected because of presence of at least one high-energy muon in the event, or because of presence of two different types on high-energy particles, such as muon and electron.

During data taking all the runs recorded by CMS are certified as good for physics analysis if all subdetectors, trigger, lumi and physics objects (tracking, electron, muon, gamma, jet and MET) show the expected performance. Certification is based first on the offline shifters evaluation and later on the feedback provided by detector and Physics Object Group experts. Based on the above information, which is stored in a specific database called Run Registry, the Data Quality Monitoring group verifies the consistency of the certification and prepares a json file of certified runs to be used for physics analysis. For each reprocessing of the raw data, the above mentioned steps are repeated. For more information see:
